title: Understanding Executive Skills
summary: Learn what executive skills are and why they are important for teens’ success.

details.content: Executive skills are the mental processes that help us plan, focus attention, remember instructions, and juggle multiple tasks. Understanding these skills helps teens and parents recognize areas of strength and challenge.
A teen who struggles with organization may forget to turn in homework, while another with strong emotional control can stay calm during stressful situations.

content: Read about the 11 executive skills described in the book.
Discuss examples of each skill in daily life.
Observe and reflect on which skills come naturally and which are more difficult.

title: Identifying Teen's Strengths and Weaknesses
summary: Assess your teen’s executive skill profile to target support and build on strengths.

details.content: Knowing a teen’s strengths and weaknesses allows for tailored strategies that maximize success and minimize frustration.
A teen with strong planning skills but weak time management may benefit from using planners and reminders.

content: Use the executive skills questionnaire from the book.
Have both parent and teen complete the assessment.
Compare results and discuss areas for growth and celebration.

title: Creating a Supportive Environment
summary: Modify the home and school environment to reduce barriers and support executive skill development.

details.content: A supportive environment reduces stress and distractions, making it easier for teens to use and strengthen their executive skills.
Setting up a dedicated, clutter-free homework space helps a teen with weak organization stay on task.

content: Establish routines for daily tasks.
Minimize distractions in work areas.
Provide visual reminders and checklists.

title: Setting Goals and Priorities
summary: Help teens set realistic goals and prioritize tasks to improve focus and motivation.

details.content: Goal setting and prioritization teach teens to break down big tasks, manage time, and stay motivated.
A teen sets a goal to improve math grades by completing all homework and seeking help when needed.

content: Use SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound) goals.
Break large goals into smaller steps.
Review progress regularly and adjust as needed.

title: Developing Time Management Skills
summary: Teach strategies for planning, scheduling, and managing time effectively.

details.content: Time management is essential for balancing school, activities, and responsibilities, reducing stress and last-minute rushes.
A teen uses a planner to map out assignments and extracurriculars, avoiding missed deadlines.

content: Use calendars or digital planners.
Set reminders for important tasks.
Encourage estimating how long tasks will take and adjusting plans as needed.

title: Improving Emotional Regulation
summary: Support teens in recognizing and managing their emotions to handle stress and frustration.

details.content: Emotional regulation helps teens cope with setbacks, avoid impulsive reactions, and maintain positive relationships.
A teen practices deep breathing before a big test to calm nerves and focus.

content: Teach relaxation techniques like deep breathing or mindfulness.
Model calm responses to stress.
Encourage talking about feelings and problem-solving.

title: Enhancing Problem-Solving Abilities
summary: Guide teens in breaking down problems and generating solutions independently.

details.content: Strong problem-solving skills empower teens to tackle challenges, make decisions, and build confidence.
A teen who forgets assignments brainstorms ways to remember, like using a checklist or phone reminders.

content: Teach a step-by-step problem-solving process: define the problem, brainstorm solutions, evaluate options, and try one.
Encourage reflection on what worked and what didn’t.
Praise effort and persistence, not just success.
